Many computer scientists have realized that, in order to productively model and study the Internet and its novel computational phenomena, they need models and insights from disciplines such as game theory and economic theory, while many economists have found that a computational point of view is essential in order to understand a world in which markets are networked and the default platforms of economic transactions are algorithmic. Algorithmic Game Theory (AGT) stands at the intersection of these two fields. It has had significant practical impact, in a broad range of applications including online, matching and assignment markets, internet advertising, information diffusion, airport security, etc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The second and last workshop of the Simons Institute Fall 2015 program on Economics and Computation, entitled “Algorithmic Game Theory and Practice” and co-organized by Eric Budish (University of Chicago), Costis Daskalakis (Massachusetts Institute of Technology), Panos Ipeirotis (New York University), Ramesh Johari (Stanford University), David Parkes (Harvard University) and Tim Roughgarden (Stanford University), took place between November 16th and 20th, 2015.

Since its birth over a decade ago, Algorithmic Game Theory (AGT) has made important theoretical contributions benefiting both Economics and Computer Science. It has also had significant practical impact, in a broad range of applications including online, matching and assignment markets, Internet advertising, information diffusion, airport security, etc. The goal of this workshop was to showcase and celebrate the contributions of Algorithmic Game Theory to practice as well as to identify application domains where AGT could have impact going forward, together with scientific challenges motivated by these applications. The workshop also explored avenues for increasing the field's practical impact, including connections to machine learning and data science.

The workshop took place over the course of four and a half days.

The line-up of speakers was absolutely outstanding, and included a Nobel laureate (Alvin Roth), the chief economists of both Microsoft and Google (Preston McAfee and Hal Varian), and strong presence from both academia (including Susan Athey, Jon Kleinberg, Andrew Lo, Paul Milgrom, Christos Papadimitriou) and industry (Microsoft, Google, Facebook and others).

The grouping of the talks was mostly thematic, but maintained a good mix to avoid heavy concentration of talks on particular subtopics. There were various subthemes including the following:

  • market design (including kidney exchanges and the sharing economy)
  • online advertising (including sponsored search and display advertising)
  • public good auctions (including spectrum auctions)
  • reputation mechanisms
  • e-democracy
  • crowdsourcing, information aggregation and machine learning
  • algorithmic trading and financial markets
  • crypto-currencies
  • social networks
  •  security games
  • game solving (including the design of poker-bots)

An interesting feature of the workshop was the “Open Directions Session” held on Thursday afternoon. The session featured discussions led by Preston McAfee and Jon Kleinberg.  McAfee formulated concrete problems motivated by cloud computing applications, while Kleinberg gave a unified perspective on recent progress and research challenges in the field of online social networks.

We designed the workshop schedule with the goal of stimulating the audience and fostering discussion among the participants. Every speaker was given a generous 40-minute slot, which allowed for presentation of plenty of the details of their work. We also maintained a relatively light schedule with at most about four hours of talks per day, allowing ample time for collaboration at the end of each day’s proceedings. We also inserted generous coffee/lunch breaks after every talk or pair of talks, with the aim of promoting post-talk discussion and collaboration.

Concrete outcomes of the workshop were the documentation of the multiple contributions of AGT to practice, and the identification of important research challenges going forward. It also served to bring a wide range of different sub-communities together to advertise their progress and receive constructive comments and suggestions. We hope that some of the interactions started during the workshop will turn into fruitful collaborations and substantive progress in the future.
